FacilityName: Sunoco Partners Mktg. & Terminals Eagle Point Term

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sunoco Partners Marketing & Terminals, L. P.
Eagle Point Terminal

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

At the Sunoco Partners Marketing & Terminals, L.P. Eagle Point Terminal in Westville, NJ, hereafter referred to as the Eagle Point Terminal, we are committed to providing a safe work environment for employees and to being a responsible corporate citizen. We believe that excellent performance in the areas of health, environment, safety and security goes hand-in-hand with operational excellence and financial success.   In fulfilling this commitment, we will comply with regulatory requirements and provide and maintain a safe working environment using acceptable and proven business practices. All Sunoco Logistics employees will strive to identify and eliminate hazards which could result in injury and illness, damage to the environment, property damage, and security losses.

The Eagle Point Terminal is operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community in which we operate.  We promote health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection.  These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning.  This summary provides a brief overview of the risk management activities that we have designed and implemented.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Eagle Point Terminal Operations include the unloading, storage and loading of crude oil and petroleum products at both dock and railcar facilities.  Crude oil and petroleum products can also be moved in and out of the terminal through pipelines.  The facility may have intermittent inventories of Butane that are stored in railcar. There is currently no processing of Butane or any other regulated substances at Eagle Point Terminal.  The terminal is classified as Program Level 3.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS

Our accidental re

lease prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help us effectively manage the hazards posed by our regulated substances to our employees, the public, and the environment.  The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as NJDEP Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act program N.J.A.C. 7:31 (1-6) and the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention programs are in place at the Eagle Point Terminal:

1)	Employee Participation
2)	Process Safety Information
3)	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) with Risk Assessments
4)	Standard Operating Procedures
5)	EHS Operator Training
6)	Contractors 
7)	Pre-startup Safety Review
8)	Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance
9)	Work Permits
10)	Management of Change
11)	EHS Accident or Potential Catastrophic Event Investigation
12)	Emergency Response
13)	Compliance Audits
14)	Trade Secrets

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Eagle Point Terminal was acquired by Sunoco Partners Marketing & Terminals, L. P. in 2011.   There have been no accidents resulting from the chemical release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation and NJDEP Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act program after the change of ownership.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

The Eagle Point Terminal maintains compliance with local, state and federal regulations including OSHA CFR 1910.120, Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and SARA Title III. The programs are reviewed and updated on an annual basis, or more often if required.  Our Emergency Response Plan provides the essential planning and training for protecting employees, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Contained within the Plan are written procedures that outline the actions to be taken for various types of emergencies that could occur in the terminal.  These emergencies may include: airborne releases of chemical substances, spills to the water or ground, fires, explosions, personnel medical emergencie

s.  The Programs address the aspects of emergency response including:

- Information on emergency organization (Incident Command System), including roles and responsibilities of personnel responding to the incident
- Procedures for notifying employees that a release has occurred
- Procedures for plant evacuation and accounting of personnel
- Procedures to notify local emergency response organizations and other appropriate authorities that a release has occurred
- Guidance on proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures
- Procedures for post incident cleanup and decontamination

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

We are continually striving to make the Eagle Point Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community.  The facility's focus is safe, reliable, and environmentally sound operations.  The goal of the Eagle Point Terminal is to demonstrate continuous improvement in our health, environmental and safety performance.  In addition, we will work cooperatively with our neighbors to ensure the health, environment, safety and security of the Eagle Point Terminal and surrounding community.
